result.title: Data Management Plan
result.description: The USFD will produce a Data Management Plan to describe how the data produced during the testing of CENTAUR will be generated, quality checked, organised and preserved. It will contain policies on accessibility, standards for collection and curation, and its preservation. The plan will also contain a policy on when data can be considered “confidential”. This policy will be agreed by all partners and will be consistent with the Collaboration Agreement. The plan will follow the EU “Guidelines on Data Management in Horizon2020”.

result.title: Marketplace demonstrator report
result.description: This document will showcase the success of one or more demonstrators of the CASEK product with an emphasis on the marketplace aspect. The document may also touch on failures in so far as they are instructive in guiding the best leverage of the CASEK product in the future. The document will take the point of view of different stakeholders in the CASEK community, for example designers, developers and end-users, but also perhaps product manufactures if products are integrated into the solution and the product manufacturers can give their input. The document is technical in nature, but includes a thorough generalist summary such that a broad audience can gain from this document, but those that are technically inclined and searching for technical details can also do so. As this is a publically disseminated document, it is intended to serve as a ressource for future stakeholder engagement with CASEK from a narrative description for a broad audience to specific technical details. The value of the CASEK product, that is to say the 'heavy lifting' that is done by the CASEK product, should be highlighted in order to convey the benefits of the CASEK product.

result.title: Business case(s) and prioritized list of common uncovered innovation needs
result.description:
Usually the brainstorming step lead to the identification of a list of desired innovative solutions, which have to be validated in comparative terms and put in order of priority, on the basis of their expected costs-benefits, impacts and trends. To validate and rank-order the perceived needs and to address the subsequent technological scanning activities (as described in WP3), this task is aimed to define business case. The business case require a straightforward articulation of the problem/needs that a procurement action is supposed to solve. It identifies the areas where there are issues that need to be addressed, such as inefficiencies, missed solutions, unacceptable market price and performance or unfavourable consumer response to a product or service already available on the market. It is very important to evaluate the historic past-performance of the process or service under consideration, using key performance indicators (KPI) as a measure (cost, headcount, time, outcomes, etc.). These KPIs have to be, then, extrapolated the future based on predictive data such as cost escalation, etc., drawn from authoritative sources in order to fix the improvements and KPIs to be achieved.
With this task we will elaborate a business, more properly “service”, case aimed to evaluate and verify the positive balance between risks and benefits for all stakeholders, reducing risk of mistakes in (procurement) decision making. Having in input the business case modelling exercise and assuming a portfolio management perspective, the task will be able to rank-order the list of needs, suitable to be addressed by (direct and/or collaborative and/or catalytic) procurement initiatives.
The business or service case, will present these information. • Problem statement: the description of the problem has to be thorough and include constraint descriptions, without attempt to prescribe the solution and should concern what is the issue, when does it happen, who is impacted and how often does it happen and what is the actual and long-term potential problem dimension. The described ‘problem’ has to be “genuine”, real, not itself questionable and not a just a symptom of a more fundamental issue. In other terms is important to determine if the problem is ‘big’ enough to justify devoting resources to solve it. To address a PCP, the problem may be predictive or anticipatory as it lies in the future, in this sense trend data are important to show the persistence and evolution of the problem. • Opportunity cost estimation: quantification of the cost (over a defined time period and within a defined geographical area) of delaying or not proceeding with the intended investment, extrapolating the future based on predictive data. • Desired solution: description in functional and performance terms the solution desired with a sufficient detail to allow the decision-makers to evaluate the solution. • Risks identification and management: assessment of the expected risks to which the project will be exposed and outline a plan to manage the risks. • Benefits analysis: identification of improvements in quality and how and when the costs will be recouped and savings will be generated. • Critical success factors and recommendations: list elaboration of the factors needed to face the market failure and ensure win-win procurement, such as the European or global scale of the demand, the need for open standards at an European level, etc.. • Reference materials Catalogue all reference materials for the business case.

result.title: Platform high-level architecture and data flows
result.description: The Data4Impact platform will be built using the D-NET Software Toolkit that is a data infrastructure “enabling software” currently used to operate known production systems (e.g. the OpenAIRE infrastructure, the EFG infrastructure, and several national repository aggregator infrastructures). D-NET will be configured, extended, and deployed to deliver the Data4Impact platform back-end, with the aim of supporting tools for scholarly communication objects aggregation and mining of publication, patent, company, social media/media, etc. data. The delivery of an operational platform, with the required computation and storage needs, will be based on an initial set of non-functional requirements to be defined in synergy with WPs 2, 4, 5 and 6.

result.title: Film with Ms < 100 kA/m, P > 60% on high-Z seed
result.description: Blanket films with Ms tuneable by temperature or doping (-100 kA/m < Ms < 100 kA/m) with a spin polarization P > 60 % grown on high-Z metal with interface roughness < 0.5 nm for spin-pumping experiments

result.title: Requirements Document
result.description: The requirements document will collate requirements from the local users/stakeholders, will receipt requirements from system already available in the demo areas and will assess and receipt the laws, limitations and best practices already present in the demo areas. The document will be prepared takiing into account existing forecasting systems in the demo areas, preparing questionnaires to be disseminated to the main stakeholders, collecting policy information and existing strategies for irrigation system development, collecting expertize in other universities and research institutions involved in previous research projects, collecting “know-how”, needs and requests at the local level (farmers in the pilot area, local administration) for irrigation used for specific types of crops, collecting the field data. The document will contain also a report of regulations, constrains, data availability, data needs and specific forecasting services and data outputs delivery requirements will be prepared. Documents

result.title: Seasonal probabilistic forecasting package
result.description: It is a set of deliverables concerning the “Seasonal probabilistic forecasting” module of MOSES platform. It includes the implemented algorithms, the SW code and the high-level procedures for the usage of the module. It will be first released at the Alpha version of the system and it will be updated, if necessary, for Beta and Release Candidate versions Delivery date: FARR (M12); PRR (M24); PA (M31)

result.title: Integrated Exploitation Platform
result.description: Integrated MOSES project GeoPortal website; the website will integrate the public website containing information on the project and the services of the Moses platform (in particular DSS), which will be accessible under the terms that will be defined during the project. Access to the code of the website will be open, while access to the code of the MOSES Service Platform and to the relevant integration code will be restricted to the Consortium. The first version of the project website will be available at M2, containing only general information on the project.
